column1: 5. Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution
At the commencement of this Constitution
column2: every person who has his domicile in the territory of India and—(a) who was born in the territory of India; or (b) either of whose parents was born in the territory of India; or (c) who has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India for not less than five years immediately preceding such commencement

column1: 6. Rights of citizenship of certain persons who have migrated to India from Pakistan

Notwithstanding anything in Article 5, a person who has migrated to the territory of India from the territory now included in Pakistan shall be deemed to be a citizen of India at the commencement of this Constitution if—(a) he or either of his parents or any of his grandparents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted); and (b)(i) if such person migrated before 19 July 1948, he has been ordinarily resident in India since the date of his migration; or (ii) if such person migrated on or after 19 July 1948, he has been registered as a citizen of India by an officer appointed in that behalf on an application made before the commencement of this Constitution: Provided that no person shall be so registered unless he has been resident in India for at least six months immediately preceding the date of his application.
7. Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan

Notwithstanding Articles 5 and 6, a person who, after 1 March 1947, migrated from India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India: Provided that this shall not apply to a person who, after having migrated to Pakistan, has returned to India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return, and such person shall be deemed to have migrated to India after 19 July 1948 for the purposes of Article 6(b).
8. Rights of citizenship of certain persons of Indian origin residing outside India

Notwithstanding Article 5, any person who or whose parents or grandparents were born in India (as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935) and is ordinarily residing outside India shall be deemed to be a citizen of India if registered as such by the diplomatic or consular representative of India.
9. Persons voluntarily acquiring citizenship of a foreign State not to be citizens
No person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of Article 5, 6, or 8 if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.
10. Continuance of the rights of citizenship
Every person who is or deemed to be a citizen under this Part shall, subject to any law made by Parliament, continue to be such citizen.
11. Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law
Nothing in this Part shall derogate from the power of Parliament to make any provision relating to citizenship, including acquisition and termination of citizenship.
12. Definition

In this Part, “the State” includes the Government and Parliament of India, the Government and Legislature of each State, and all local or other authorities within India or under the control of the Government of India.
13. Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of fundamental rights

(1) All pre-Constitution laws inconsistent with this Part shall be void to the extent of inconsistency. (2) The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges fundamental rights; any such law shall be void to the extent of contravention. (3) “Law” includes any ordinance, order, by-law, rule, regulation, notification, custom, or usage. (4) Constitutional amendments under Article 368 are not subject to Article 13.
14. Equality before law
The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws in India.
15. Prohibition of discrimination

(1) The State shall not discriminate on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. (2) No citizen shall face discrimination in access to public places. (3) Special provision for women and children is permitted. (4) Special provisions for socially and educationally backward classes, SCs, and STs. (5) Special provisions for their admission in educational institutions (including private). (6) Special provisions for Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) up to 10% reservation. Explanation: “Economically weaker sections” shall be notified by the State based on family income and disadvantage indicators.
16. Equality of opportunity in public employment

(1) Equality of opportunity in public employment. (2) No discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, or residence. (3) Parliament may prescribe residence requirements. (4) Reservation for backward classes not adequately represented. (4A) Reservation in promotions for SC/ST. (4B) Carry-forward of unfilled reserved vacancies allowed. (5) Religious institutions may require incumbents to profess a particular religion. (6) Up to 10% EWS reservation in appointments.
17. Abolition of Untouchability
Untouchability is abolished; enforcement of any disability arising out of it shall be an offence.
18. Abolition of titles

(1) No titles except military or academic distinctions. (2) No Indian citizen shall accept titles from foreign States. (3) Non-citizens in State service require Presidential consent to accept titles. (4) Presidential consent required to accept foreign gifts/office.
19. Protection of certain rights

All citizens have the right—(a) freedom of speech and expression; (b) to assemble peaceably without arms; (c) to form associations or unions or cooperative societies; (d) to move freely throughout India; (e) to reside and settle anywhere; (g) to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade, or business; with reasonable restrictions in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, public order, decency, morality, contempt of court, defamation, and incitement.
20. Protection in respect of conviction for offences
(1) No ex post facto laws. (2) No double jeopardy. (3) No self-incrimination.
21. Protection of life and personal liberty
No person shall be deprived of life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
21A. Right to education
The State shall provide free and compulsory education to children aged 6–14 years.
22. Protection against arrest and detention

Includes rights to be informed of grounds of arrest, consult a lawyer, and be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours; includes rules on preventive detention, Advisory Boards, maximum periods, and procedural safeguards.
23. Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour
(1) Human trafficking, begar, and forced labour are prohibited. (2) State may impose compulsory public service without discrimination.
24. Prohibition of child labour
No child below 14 years shall work in a factory, mine, or hazardous employment.
25. Freedom of conscience and religion
Subject to public order, morality, and health; allows profession, practice, and propagation of religion; State may regulate secular activities and enact social reform.
26. Freedom to manage religious affairs
Right to establish institutions, manage religious affairs, own property, and administer such property.
27. No taxation for promotion of any particular religion
No person shall be compelled to pay taxes for promoting any particular religion.
28. Religious instruction in educational institutions
Religious instruction prohibited in State-funded institutions except those established under endowments requiring it.
29. Protection of interests of minorities
(1) Right to conserve language, script, culture. (2) No discrimination in admission to educational institutions.
30. Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions
Includes protection against acquisition of property without proper compensation.
32. Remedies for enforcement of fundamental rights
Right to approach the Supreme Court; Court may issue writs—habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, certiorari.
33. Power of Parliament to modify fundamental rights for Armed Forces etc.
Parliament may restrict rights for Armed Forces, police, intelligence services.
34. Restrictions during martial law
Parliament may indemnify persons acting under martial law and impose restrictions.
35. Legislation to give effect to this Part
Parliament has exclusive power relating to offences, penalties, and procedural matters for enforcing fundamental rights.

column1: 372. Continuance in force of existing laws and their adaptation

(1) All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of the Constitution shall continue in force until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or authority.
